I‚Äôve spoken many times about the importance of partnership as we tackle the energy transition and develop New Energies solutions.  In that spirit, I‚Äôm delighted to share that today Chevron announced a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Air Liquide, Keppel Infrastructure and PetroChina to create a consortium that intends to evaluate and advance the development of large-scale carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) solutions and integrated infrastructure in Singapore.  

Through research, testing and operational solutions, the consortium aims to provide industry-wide CCUS infrastructure to support the energy and chemicals sector by capturing CO2 emissions to utilize for making useful products like plastics and cement, or by transporting the CO2 to geological reservoirs in the Asia Pacific region for permanent and secure storage.
 
We believe that the future of energy is lower carbon.  This strategic alliance with like-minded collaborators will help us progress and advance the development of large-scale CCUS solutions in the Asia Pacific region for decades to come. 

https://lnkd.in/gFV9HN5Y

#CCUS #CCS #energytransition #energyevolution #partnerships #chevronnewenergies #singapore

I am delighted to share that through our local subsidiary, Chevron Australia, we have been granted an interest in three greenhouse gas assessment permits offshore Australia.  The acreage totals nearly 7.8 million acres ‚Äì an area larger than Belgium.   
¬†
Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is expected to play an essential role in reducing carbon emissions in hard to abate, energy intensive industries like refining, petrochemical, power, cement, and steel.¬†These new greenhouse gas assessment permits have the potential to expand Chevron's portfolio of CCS assets in the Asia-Pacific region.
¬†
We look forward to collaborating with our joint venture partners to define the potential in these blocks, located in the Carnarvon and Bonaparte Basins, and explore the possibilities to provide lower carbon solutions for our customers and stakeholders in the region.¬†
¬†
Read more here:¬† https://lnkd.in/gAc469ru

Our tug boats on Barrow Island had some very special visitors last weekend, with a female humpback whale and her calf swimming into the boat pen while on their annual migration between the¬†Kimberley and the Antarctic.

We've seen plenty of sea turtles,¬†small sharks and groups of dolphins¬†‚Äì and even rare sightings of dugongs -¬†¬†but this is the first time we‚Äôre aware of that a pair of whales have been seen in the pens.

Migrating whales make stops to rest and feed their calves, and as with many locations along the WA coast,¬†they are common¬†around Barrow Island during the migration season. In this case, they stayed in the pens for around 40 minutes before continuing on their journey.

Thanks to Cindy and Rima from Toll for capturing this incredible footage!

So many #manufacturing innovations made #TeamBoeing a leader in aerospace.

Following World War I, engineers focused on designing more practical and efficient aircraft. Traditional stick, wire and fabric construction gave way to a welded steel framework and duralumin. In 1923, Boeing engineers successfully devised the process of arc-welding light steel tubing. This innovation was used to build the PW-9, the first Boeing-designed fighter.

This month, we‚Äôre partnering with the Albertsons Companies Women‚Äôs Inspiration and Inclusion Network to recognize Breast Cancer Awareness Month and share the stories of associates whose lives have been touched by breast cancer. Pam Stevens, Store Director in our Portland Division, has been on our team since 1988 and was diagnosed with Ductal Carcinoma in 2015.
 
Pam shares: ‚ÄúHearing I had breast cancer was devastating, but I faced it head on and every day started with a positive attitude. I won't lie, it was the toughest thing I had ever been through.‚Äù
 
We‚Äôre thrilled to share that Pam has been cancer-free for over six years! She credits family, friends and teammates for showing up for her during diagnosis and treatment and for helping her put herself first.
 
‚ÄúI had the best support team at Store #0400. I was determined to go through chemo and work as long as I could. I made it to my 3rd round out of 8. My Store Director, Tiffany Knottingham, is the most supportive manager that I could have had. She said, 'Pammy, you need to go and take care of yourself. We will all be waiting for you when you return to work.' I did return, 9 weeks later, and I am still here with a smile on my face.‚Äù 
 
Pam encourages those who have a loved one facing a cancer diagnosis to show up ‚Äì no matter what. ‚ÄúReach out and offer help or just show up. We all say ‚Äòwe are fine‚Äô or ‚Äòwe don't need help‚Äô but trust me, we are not. We do need you.‚Äù
 
Pam‚Äôs number one tip for you? ‚ÄúIt can happen to anyone. Please get your mammograms. I was lucky and caught mine early. Don't wait because it may be too late.‚Äù
 
Pam, thank you for sharing your story. We are one team and we're glad you're part of our family. We're so happy to celebrate you today!

Good people are everywhere ‚Äì and one such 'angel' showed up at Star Market in Auburndale, MA last Thursday.

While in the checkout line, 89-year-old Marilyn Oettingger discovered her credit card had been canceled just days earlier. Marilyn was confused and embarrassed, but a mystery customer stepped up, saved the day and paid for her groceries.

The mystery customer left before Marilyn could gather his info so the Oettingger family has taken to social media to find him. Even if they don't locate Marilyn's 'angel', the family pledges to pay it forward during future trips to Star Market. 

Thank you, mystery Star Market customer, for making a positive difference in the life of Marilyn Oettingger!

Catherine Brown, Store Director at Safeway in Falcon, CO, has been in retail for 27 years and has spent more than a decade on the Albertsons Companies team. ‚ÄúI want to express my profound gratitude to Cathryn, Store Director at the Falcon, CO Safeway store. My wife and I suffered the complete destruction of our small ranch in New Mexico due to wildfires. We escaped with our car & pick-up truck loaded with photos and precious things. We came to our kid's home here in Falcon and went shopping at the local Safeway. I asked Cathryn for directions to the COVID test kit location in the store. She took me right to the shelf. We engaged in some conversation and I told her what happened and why we were here.¬†

She immediately took my basket of groceries, including the test kits up the self checkout and checked me out using her personal credit card. I was never so surprised in all my life. I was not expecting such kindness for a complete stranger. You have some exceptional folks working in your stores. Your corporate culture in my eyes helped foster this kind of attitude and service to the community. I hope that she will receive some kind of recognition for her absolute compassion and kindness.‚Äù

Albertsons Companies has deployed a new online service for Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) recipients at Albertsons, Safeway, Jewel-Osco, VONS, and Pavilions stores across the country. 

The integration of EBT services enables SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) customers to use their benefits when purchasing groceries online via the Albertsons Companies websites and apps, as well as Albertsons Companies virtual stores on the Instacart App, ensuring that families and individuals who rely on EBT SNAP benefits have greater access to nutritious food.

This month, we‚Äôre celebrating the stories of five incredible associates who are part of the Albertsons Pride Alliance, one of our many Associate Resource Groups (ARGs) dedicated to providing support, enhancing career development, and contributing to personal development in the work environment.

Helen Dalton has been part of the Albertsons Companies team for 11 years and currently works as Labor Relations Manager in our Southwest Division. Helen is a proud member of the Southwest Division‚Äôs Diversity and Inclusion Council as well as the Albertsons Pride Alliance ARG, and is an active volunteer with the ACI Crisis Response Team.

Helen recognizes the importance of resource groups such as the Pride Alliance and Diversity and Inclusion Council in the workplace. ‚ÄúFor far too long, LGBTQ+ individuals had to compartmentalize themselves in order to be accepted in certain social and work environments. No one should ever have to hide or feel shame for who they are or who they love.

I encourage anyone and everyone at Albertsons Companies to join as many ARGs as possible. Share your story and truly listen to the stories of others. Realize your own subconscious biases and strive every day to overcome them. We are all in this together and together we can affect great change.‚Äù

We‚Äôre thankful to have Helen as a champion of diversity and inclusion at Albertsons Companies and proud to shine the spotlight on an amazing associate today.¬† #PrideMonth

We're thrilled to celebrate associate Ethan Teicher, who has been named an ABC7 Community Champion in El Paso, TX!

We‚Äôre honored to celebrate the stories and perspectives of our incredible associates this #PrideMonth! Steve Henry (he/him/his) has been on the Albertsons Companies team for nearly 19 years, starting out pushing carts in the snowy New Hampshire weather and currently working as Director, Data Quality and Shelf Communication in our Pleasanton office.

Steve shares: ‚ÄúPride is about two things for me: joy and being boldly, unapologetically visible. Many LGBTQ+ folks spend a portion or majority of their formative years (and beyond) hiding a piece of themselves from everyone around them and often (not always) that comes with a lot of shame.¬† Pride is about reclaiming space and rejecting the closet that held a lot of us back and continues to hold back others who can‚Äôt come out yet because they‚Äôre not ready or it‚Äôs not safe to do so.‚Äù

What does it mean to Steve to be a member of the LGBTQ+ community?¬†

"My journey is different than a straight person‚Äôs ‚Äì just like my journey as a cisgendered man is very different from someone in the trans community. I get to see the world a bit differently because of that and I‚Äôm honestly super thankful that I do. I think it‚Äôs challenged me to be a better ally to other marginalized groups within the LGBTQ community and outside of it. It‚Äôs also allowed me to create a really wonderful chosen family in addition to my birth one (who are fantastic, too!).¬† I would never want to erase any part of me ‚Äì including the less than great experiences ‚Äì because I‚Äôm pretty proud of the gay man I‚Äôve become and continue to become."

We're grateful to have Steve on the Albertsons Companies team and as a member of the Albertsons Pride Alliance.

In honor of Asian American Pacific Islander Heritage Month, we spoke with Albertsons Companies Senior Food Technologist and Asian Network ARG member, Carly Ogata MS, RDN. Carly comes from a Japanese-American family with a rich culture that has also overcome great hardship ‚Äì many family members were placed in internment camps during WWII.¬†

She credits her mom as being her greatest inspiration. ‚ÄúIn 2019, my brother and mom bought Ota Tofu in Portland, OR. Ota is the oldest tofu company in America that makes tofu by hand using traditional Japanese methods. My mom went from being a part-time optometrist to working full-time with my brother at Ota Tofu, which is not easy work. On top of that, she leads a group of volunteers that make over 100 Japanese-style bento lunches for homebound seniors every month. Despite constantly being busy and mentally and physically tired from work, she has a big heart and makes the time to help others.‚Äù

In honor of #BreastCancerAwareness Month, JCPenney is proud to partner with nonprofit organization HairToStay.Org and donate $50,000 to help fund hair-preserving, scalp cooling treatments for low-income cancer patients going through chemotherapy. According to HairToStay, approximately eight percent of cancer patients will elect to not go through chemotherapy, a potentially life-saving treatment, because of the fear of hair loss.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†
‚ÄúOur stylists work with our clients every day, and they‚Äôre some of the first people our clients typically call after a cancer diagnosis. They‚Äôll explain they need a ‚Äòchemo cut‚Äô in preparation for losing their hair during treatment,‚Äù said Lori Moran Chumley, Director of Salon Operations and Communication. ‚ÄúAs a breast cancer survivor myself, I thought about how magical it would be for us to be able to share with those clients that they don‚Äôt have to lose their hair ‚Äì that there‚Äôs another option during chemo treatment.‚Äù¬†

The Phillips 66 Humber Refinery in the UK will be the first refinery in the world to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions using technology pioneered by Shell Catalysts & Technologies. This technology will help compress the carbon dioxide in FCC flue gas before it is transported to be safely stored in geological structures deep under the North Sea. This innovative technology supports Humber Zero, a first-of-a-kind project that could provide a model to help decarbonize refineries and advance the UK‚Äôs net-zero target.

The Phillips 66 Humber Refinery in the UK will be the first refinery in the world to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions using technology pioneered by Shell Catalysts & Technologies. This technology will help compress the carbon dioxide in FCC flue gas before it is transported to be safely stored in geological structures deep under the North Sea. This innovative technology supports Humber Zero, a first-of-a-kind project that could provide a model to help decarbonize refineries and advance the UK‚Äôs net-zero target.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gay-UhxZ

For over 50 years, the Phillips 66 Humber Refinery has supplied essential fuels and products, from chemical processing products to components of lithium-ion batteries. Thank you, Union Pacific Railroad Community Ties Giving Program, for investing in A New Leaf‚Äôs East Valley Emergency Shelter Programs, serving communities along Union Pacific‚Äôs east-west line, traveling the width of the state from Yuma to San Simon!

This support will make an immediate impact by providing safe shelter and basic needs for 1,200 families and individuals in crisis, and a long-term impact by helping households achieve housing stability and financial self-sufficiency to prevent or overcome homelessness and poverty.

In 2022, the Point In Time Count documented 1,170 individuals experiencing homelessness in a single night in the East Valley of the Phoenix Metro Area, which is a 109% increase since 2018!

A New Leaf has over 51 years of experience providing comprehensive, wrap-around support services including emergency shelter and housing resources and support, access to medical care, afterschool programming for youth, counseling, court advocacy, financial empowerment, employment assistance, and more. 

By providing individualized services and support to address each individual‚Äôs needs, A New Leaf strives to address the root causes of their challenges and to help households overcome barriers to sustainable stability, health and success.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women in the United States. Despite a lower incidence rate, Black and African American women are 41 percent more likely to die from breast cancer than Caucasian women. 

Angela Fielding, Co-President of the IMPACT Network Resource Group and Director of Provider Experience and Network Transformation/Humana Healthy Horizons, is a 3-year breast cancer survivor.  

Angela shares her story of being diagnosed with breast cancer. She also discusses the importance of access to and utilization of sophisticated digital diagnostic techniques to detect breast cancer in women with dense breasts and women of color. 

‚ÄúThe message that I want to share with women, particularly Black and African American women about my experience, is that early detection is essential to survival,‚Äù said Angela.‚ÄØ‚ÄúWe must ensure that we are being intentional about getting breast cancer screenings.‚ÄØEarly detection was due to vigilance with my examinations and self-advocacy.‚Äù 

Read Angela‚Äôs powerful story and learn simple actions you can take to improve breast cancer outcomes in women ‚Üí https://huma.na/3g2bJ1V 

#BreastCancerAwarenessMonth #HealthEquity

The Humana Foundation is donating $1 million towards relief and recovery efforts for those impacted by Hurricane Ian in Florida and Hurricane Fiona in Puerto Rico. Humana has also taken steps to aid communities in each storm‚Äôs path, including opening access to a crisis hotline with free counseling available.

Humana has established a crisis intervention hotline through LifeWorks, with free counseling services for anyone ‚Äì Humana members and non-members alike ‚Äì who may need help and support to cope with the disaster and its consequences. The LifeWorks Crisis Support Line is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week and can be reached at 1-877-757-7587 in the United States and Puerto Rico.

‚ÄúFor those of us who live on the Gulf Coast, this was a scary week, and it means a great deal to us to be working with the Humana Foundation to now help the people who suffered the most as the hurricane crossed our state,‚Äù added Jocelyn Chisholm Carter, JD, president of Humana Healthy Horizons, Humana‚Äôs Medicaid business in Florida. Carter resides in Tampa. ‚ÄúOur message to the people we are fortunate to serve is that we will be there for you in the days ahead.‚Äù

In addition, Humana, Dr. Traci‚Äôs House and Rebuilt Meals joined forces to help families in need.  The coalition distributed healthy and prepackaged individual meals to households on a first-come, first-served basis. The event was held on Saturday at Dr. Traci‚Äôs House, 904 E. Henry Ave.

For those who may be impacted by Hurricanes Fiona and Ian, your safety and well-being remain a top priority. We hope you and your family are staying safe during and in the aftermath of the storms. The following steps are being taken to assist our members in declared disaster areas: 

  -  Waiving all requirements for primary care physician (PCP) referrals and prior authorizations for members 
  -  Providing members with the same cost sharing they would receive from an in-network facility even if receiving care outside the network 
  -  For members with a pharmacy benefit, suspended restrictions on refills to allow for travel difficulties and evacuations
  -  We have also established a free crisis support hotline and counseling services through LifeWorks, aimed not only at health plan employees and members, but also at anyone who may need help and support in the U.S. to cope with the disaster and its consequences. The LifeWorks Crisis Support Line is open 24/7 and can be reached at 1-877-757-7587 in the United States.

Humana members with questions about services available to them should call the toll-free phone number on the back of their Humana ID card. 

More information and additional resources can be found here ‚Üí https://huma.na/3RoyEkK

To recognize Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, we spoke with associates who honor the Jewish High Holidays about family, work and the meaning of the holidays. Meet Melissa Elbrand Blum, Population Health Strategy Lead, South Florida Bold Goal Community, who has worked for Humana for almost 17 years.

‚ÄúA big misconception is that you celebrate Yom Kippur,‚Äù said Melissa. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our day of atonement, where we fast from sundown the night before to sundown the next day. It‚Äôs a somber day. It‚Äôs the holiest day of the year. It‚Äôs not a day of celebration.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI love that I work for a company that values inclusion and diversity,‚Äù said Melissa. ‚ÄúOver the past year I have had ‚Äòcandid conversations‚Äô with colleagues of different faiths and races to better understand their culture, religions and beliefs while sharing mine. Organ donation saves lives. Living donors who provide vital organs, such as kidney, liver or lung, can often be identified through simple blood tests. Currently, ethnic minorities form the majority (60%) of the more than 105,000 people on the US transplant waiting list, but only 30% of the donor population. 

Born in the Philippines, Michael Frias, Humana associate, was a perfect match to donate a kidney to his wife, Natalie. Although they do not share the same ethnicity, transplant surgery was successful and Natalie and Michael enjoy life raising their 2 children, MJ and Calia, in Michigan. 

On National Minority Donor Awareness Day, Michael encourages others to become organ donors too. Humana honors the contribution of multicultural donors and their families, while recognizing the need for increased organ donation among the African American, Hispanic, Asian/Pacific Islander and Native American communities. 

Hear from Michael and Natalie as they share their kidney donation story and learn more about what life is like for them as partners, parents and advocates for kidney health and donation ‚Üí https://huma.na/3zIoANZ

You‚Äôve got a lot on your plate, so we‚Äôve got you covered with this short refresher of the four types of disability coverage. 

1. Short-term disability insurance
Covers employees for around three to six months when a temporary covered illness or injury keeps them out of work.

2. Long-term disability insurance
Benefits can extend for years or even until employees reach retirement age, but usually pay out less than short-term policies and can be more costly.

3. Social Security Disability Insurance
Only covers employees who are completely unable to work due to a severe, long-term, total disability, if they have paid Social Security taxes.

4. Workers‚Äô compensation insurance
Only covers workplace-sustained injuries or illnesses, with the company filing a claim on behalf of the employee with whomever processes claims in your state.

We're pleased to share an exciting development relating to our AI innovation.

AI-Ready DigitalBoard: 

https://lnkd.in/g-G5HWsq

This is one of the latest AI innovation to help board directors assess and evaluate how effective their companies are. While the analytical contents are generated by Ai, the humans are still needed to explain to their stakeholders and connect with them on the issues highlighted and the action steps that need to be pursued.

These have been rolled out and used by PLC board directors globally: non-exec chairpersons, non-executive independent directors, risk committee heads, advisors to boards and more.

Four Interesting Facts of this AI System:

1. Can compress hundreds of pages of contents, into understandable format that is succinct and clear. You can also make request to modify the format and add your own parameters.

2. Covers implications of business and financial strategies, risk assessment, six capitals (integrated reporting), sentiment analysis surrounding the organisation, leadership profile / traits and comparing against top leaders and more.

3. For boardroom size of 5, 7 9 , 11 and 13 (directors), the report cost per director is lower than the price of an intern's pay, and even so for a CFO - to give you foresight and recommendations based on internal and external dynamics of the firm.

4. It has been successfully forward and back tested on thousands of companies that experienced credit downgrades, defaults or fundamental issues.

Recent press releases on DigitalBoard:

https://bit.ly/3OGgxqC 

#innovation #business #ai #teamworkapac #myfinb #ceaiglobal

Heard at ANA Association of National Advertisers Audio Summit:

The safety of researchers is a hugely important consideration when conducting qualitative fieldwork. 
¬†
We recently attended The AQR Safety Guidance webinar which
provided practical insights into keeping researchers safe. Our key takeaways from the newly published guidance are:
¬†
- Always check in with researchers before and after qualitative
fieldwork (especially when in-person!)
¬†
- Make space for concerns to be raised and addressed before
fieldwork begins
¬†
- Create a checklist for preparing for all qualitative fieldwork
¬†
- Personal characteristics of researchers e.g., gender, ethnicity,
sexuality can affect their experience conducting research. Check if people are comfortable working on projects and allow them to express their feelings of
discomfort.
¬†
As our work at Progressive spans a wide range of fields, from going into prisons to exploring personal health needs with seldom heard groups, this guidance will be an invaluable reference point for us when undertaking qual research in future.
¬†
You can find the guidance here:
https://lnkd.in/eAS9VwQM 

#qualitativeresearch #safeatwork

***CALLING ALL SHORT-TERM HOLIDAY LET HOSTS***

We are conducting research on behalf of the Scottish Government, testing some advertising about legislation passed in January 2022 introducing a licensing scheme for short-term holiday let accommodation. Short-term holiday let accommodation includes anything from guesthouses to B&Bs, self-catering cottages to yurts.

We will be running focus groups with anyone who shares/lets their home (or second home) in Scotland, gathering their feedback on the advertising.

The focus groups will run on the 5th and 6th September, over the video-conferencing platform Zoom. They will last roughly 90 minutes, and you will be reimbursed ¬£50 for your time.

If the following apply to you:

¬∑¬†You own B&B, guesthouse, Airbnb or self-catering accommodation in Scotland that is either your primary residence or a secondary letting (but not a hotel or a licensed caravan park);
¬∑¬†You rent this accommodation out on a short-term basis to different guests (either all or part of the home); and
¬∑¬†You are available to participate in one of these focus groups.

Please reply to this message and we can arrange a time to speak.

Thanks!

Sustainability and protecting our planet are ongoing and pressing topics. I cast my mind back to November 2021, when I attended the Market Research Society (MRS) Sustainability Summit. This was full-day virtual event. The day consisted of panel discussions, guest speakers and presentations of findings; all revolving around the topic of sustainability. Each of the sessions lasted around 30 minutes, the guests would then do a Q&A with the host, using questions posted on the live chat by attendees. It was an interactive day with lots of interesting things discussed, some of which I‚Äôve picked out below. 

Key messages:
One of the most interesting factors affecting progress towards a sustainable future was the gap between action and intention, sometimes called the ‚Äòsay-do‚Äô gap. Ipsos Mori have identified this gap as the biggest factor affecting people‚Äôs behaviour. There is also a call for more research to be done on people‚Äôs current actions rather than what they would like to achieve in the future. It will give a real insight into our current situation and how far we‚Äôve got to go.

Another key insight was that changes in consumer behaviour can be linked to how a brand or product is perceived. People like to know their purchase is having a direct, positive impact on the environment, such as trees planted after you buy a certain product. This lends itself to the authenticity of brands but is also open to a key criticism of businesses: ‚Äògreen washing‚Äô. Green washing is the perception that brands do not back up their claims around green activities with concrete actions. Certain products seem sustainable and environmentally friendly but are having the opposite effect and are marketed to deceive the consumer.

How we will react -
As an industry, we need to reflect on these key messages, and put our actions into practice. It‚Äôs really about the small steps and then the big things take care of themselves. 
#marketresearch #research #sustainability

Jonnie, one of our Execs, ran his first-ever focus groups last week ‚Äì brand testing for a charity relaunching its branding assets.
¬†
Here are his (mostly practical) do's and don'ts for any online focus groups you might be running in the near future:
¬†
Do: write the ‚Äòlive‚Äô time you expect to finish each section of the topic/discussion guide. So, if you are running a group that lasts one hour, starts at 6pm, and the first section of the topic guide lasts 10 minutes, stick 6-6.10pm in the margin! Do this for each section of your topic guide. This will help you stay on track, meaning you won‚Äôt need to rush the backend of the guide (which can often be the most critical!)
¬†
Do: make sure you have a way of telling the time, such as a phone or watch. You need it to stay on track, but it‚Äôs particularly important if you are moderating groups online and sharing content for the discussion because you may not be able to see the time whilst sharing your screen.
¬†
Do: log on to the call early. This will give you enough time to make sure that the call is recording properly, you are able to share stimulus, and test anything that requires more technical setup (such as sharing your computer‚Äôs audio for any TV and radio adverts). It also gives you time to settle and practice your opening lines!
¬†
Don‚Äôt: try to take detailed notes and moderate at the same time. If you‚Äôre recording the group, focus on being attentive to what is being said and probe accordingly ‚Äì you can always listen back to the recording to clarify your understanding of certain points and pick out quotes. If you‚Äôre not recording the interview, it could be worth seeing if a colleague would be free to help you out with notetaking!
¬†
Don‚Äôt: spend too much time on introductions and warm up. It can be easy to get carried away with ‚Äòwhere do you live?‚Äô and ‚Äòwhat do you do for a living?‚Äô type questions, but it‚Äôs good to get into the main discussion as soon as possible. If you feel your group participants are spending too long on their introductions, reiterate that you‚Äôre just after a brief one/two-line intro.

#research  #focusgroup #brand #testing

The safety of researchers is a hugely important consideration when conducting qualitative fieldwork. 
¬†
We recently attended The AQR Safety Guidance webinar which
provided practical insights into keeping researchers safe. Our key takeaways from the newly published guidance are:
¬†
- Always check in with researchers before and after qualitative
fieldwork (especially when in-person!)
¬†
- Make space for concerns to be raised and addressed before
fieldwork begins
¬†
- Create a checklist for preparing for all qualitative fieldwork
¬†
- Personal characteristics of researchers e.g., gender, ethnicity,
sexuality can affect their experience conducting research. Check if people are comfortable working on projects and allow them to express their feelings of
discomfort.
¬†
As our work at Progressive spans a wide range of fields, from going into prisons to exploring personal health needs with seldom heard groups, this guidance will be an invaluable reference point for us when undertaking qual research in future.
¬†
You can find the guidance here:
https://lnkd.in/eAS9VwQM 

#qualitativeresearch #safeatwork

***CALLING ALL SHORT-TERM HOLIDAY LET HOSTS***

We are conducting research on behalf of the Scottish Government, testing some advertising about legislation passed in January 2022 introducing a licensing scheme for short-term holiday let accommodation. Short-term holiday let accommodation includes anything from guesthouses to B&Bs, self-catering cottages to yurts.

We will be running focus groups with anyone who shares/lets their home (or second home) in Scotland, gathering their feedback on the advertising.

Sustainability and protecting our planet are ongoing and pressing topics. I cast my mind back to November 2021, when I attended the Market Research Society (MRS) Sustainability Summit. This was full-day virtual event. The day consisted of panel discussions, guest speakers and presentations of findings; all revolving around the topic of sustainability. Each of the sessions lasted around 30 minutes, the guests would then do a Q&A with the host, using questions posted on the live chat by attendees. It was an interactive day with lots of interesting things discussed, some of which I‚Äôve picked out below. 

Key messages:
One of the most interesting factors affecting progress towards a sustainable future was the gap between action and intention, sometimes called the ‚Äòsay-do‚Äô gap. Ipsos Mori have identified this gap as the biggest factor affecting people‚Äôs behaviour. There is also a call for more research to be done on people‚Äôs current actions rather than what they would like to achieve in the future. It will give a real insight into our current situation and how far we‚Äôve got to go.

Another key insight was that changes in consumer behaviour can be linked to how a brand or product is perceived. People like to know their purchase is having a direct, positive impact on the environment, such as trees planted after you buy a certain product. This lends itself to the authenticity of brands but is also open to a key criticism of businesses: ‚Äògreen washing‚Äô. Green washing is the perception that brands do not back up their claims around green activities with concrete actions. Certain products seem sustainable and environmentally friendly but are having the opposite effect and are marketed to deceive the consumer.

How we will react -
As an industry, we need to reflect on these key messages, and put our actions into practice. It‚Äôs really about the small steps and then the big things take care of themselves. 
#marketresearch #research #sustainability

Last Thursday, we confirmed we were withdrawing from Russia. Since then, we have been working with local partners to dispose of all of our investment positions.

We have been planning an orderly process to ensure continuity of services for clients and to provide a future for our Russian colleagues, some who have been with Omnicom for decades. We expect to finalize details shortly.

As the violence and humanitarian crisis continues in Ukraine, our number one priority remains the safety and well-being of our more than 200 colleagues and their families there. We are in constant contact with our Ukrainian agency leaders and supporting our people with much needed humanitarian assistance, including transportation, accommodations, visa and working papers, translation services, relocation support, supplies and medical support.

We continue to keep our affected colleagues in our thoughts and hope for peace.

Be part of shaping the future of creative work.
¬†¬†
More than two years of remote working have disrupted how we live, work, and create. TBWA\Worldwide is conducting research to gather information on the seismic shifts impacting the culture of work, especially the culture of creative work, so our industry can create a better way forward.

Last Thursday, we confirmed we were withdrawing from Russia. Since then, we have been working with local partners to dispose of all of our investment positions.

We have been planning an orderly process to ensure continuity of services for clients and to provide a future for our Russian colleagues, some who have been with Omnicom for decades. We expect to finalize details shortly.

As the violence and humanitarian crisis continues in Ukraine, our number one priority remains the safety and well-being of our more than 200 colleagues and their families there. We are in constant contact with our Ukrainian agency leaders and supporting our people with much needed humanitarian assistance, including transportation, accommodations, visa and working papers, translation services, relocation support, supplies and medical support.

We continue to keep our affected colleagues in our thoughts and hope for peace.

I‚Äôve spoken many times about the importance of partnership as we tackle the energy transition and develop New Energies solutions.  In that spirit, I‚Äôm delighted to share that today Chevron announced a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Air Liquide, Keppel Infrastructure and PetroChina to create a consortium that intends to evaluate and advance the development of large-scale carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) solutions and integrated infrastructure in Singapore.  

Through research, testing and operational solutions, the consortium aims to provide industry-wide CCUS infrastructure to support the energy and chemicals sector by capturing CO2 emissions to utilize for making useful products like plastics and cement, or by transporting the CO2 to geological reservoirs in the Asia Pacific region for permanent and secure storage.
 
We believe that the future of energy is lower carbon.  This strategic alliance with like-minded collaborators will help us progress and advance the development of large-scale CCUS solutions in the Asia Pacific region for decades to come. 

https://lnkd.in/gFV9HN5Y

#CCUS #CCS #energytransition #energyevolution #partnerships #chevronnewenergies #singapore

Our tug boats on Barrow Island had some very special visitors last weekend, with a female humpback whale and her calf swimming into the boat pen while on their annual migration between the¬†Kimberley and the Antarctic.

We've seen plenty of sea turtles,¬†small sharks and groups of dolphins¬†‚Äì and even rare sightings of dugongs -¬†¬†but this is the first time we‚Äôre aware of that a pair of whales have been seen in the pens.

Migrating whales make stops to rest and feed their calves, and as with many locations along the WA coast,¬†they are common¬†around Barrow Island during the migration season. In this case, they stayed in the pens for around 40 minutes before continuing on their journey.

Thanks to Cindy and Rima from Toll for capturing this incredible footage!

Have you ever heard the famous Nordstrom Tire Story? It all started when an employee of ours received a strange request from a customer 40 years ago in Fairbanks, Alaska. Different versions of the story have been told over the years and some question whether it‚Äôs even true ‚Äì that‚Äôs why this week on The Nordy Pod, we‚Äôre settling the debate once and for all. ¬†
¬†
Our host Pete Nordstrom tracked the employee himself to hear firsthand what happened. And as it turns out? Everything you've heard is true, and serves as an extreme example of what‚Äôs possible when our teams are empowered to use their best judgment in every customer interaction. ¬†
¬†
It‚Äôs held such an important role in strengthening our whole customer service ethos, and we‚Äôre excited to share it with you.

15% of clinical trial sites never enroll a single participant. The sites that do find participants often take years to complete enrollment. Almost half the time spent on bringing a drug through clinical trials is during the enrollment phase. This causes serious delays in getting drugs to patients who need them now. 

Amgen‚Äôs solution? Follow the data. Enter ATOMIC, a cross-functional project that leverages data and advanced analytics to help predict successful clinical trial sites and uncover hidden gems.

The 2022 summit is next month and will feature a diverse group of Kiewit leaders. 

Our partnership with the Thurgood Marshall College Fund (TMCF) was established in 2022. In February, 20 Historically Black College & University (HBCU) students attended a two-day immersion event at Kiewit University in Omaha, Nebraska. During the event, students engaged with Kiewit employees from across the organization, who shared insights about their career journeys at Kiewit. Eight attendees interned with us this past summer and are receiving scholarship support for the 2022-2023 school year.

Our Women in Kiewit and Legacy Minority Scholarships, launched in 2018 and 2019, respectively, have supported the collegiate careers of 33 students. Recipients, who are dependents of Kiewit employees and majoring in construction or engineering fields, receive $5,000 per semester for four years, as well as internship opportunities with Kiewit.

Important information to potential job candidates. 
 
Individuals unaffiliated with Kiewit are sending out fake employment offers in an attempt to fraud job candidates. Please understand that Kiewit does not solicit candidates for employment via email ‚Äì nor do we require fees or payment during any part of the recruitment or hiring process. 
 
If someone solicits information or money from you as part of the ‚Äúrecruitment process‚Äù or as an employment offer, you should assume that the communication is not from Kiewit and is not sanctioned or approved by our Company. ‚ÄúMy husband Jayson and I started JLM by building an office desk using only a ‚ÄúL‚Äù wrench and we turned our dining room into a staffing office back in 2011. We uncovered a huge need for professional talent in the construction and infrastructure industries, so we decided to go all in and dedicate all our resources to the construction and infrastructure industries. As we continue our efforts to build meaningful relationships with small and diverse businesses in our communities to enhance our projects, we get to know leaders doing great work to engage and mentor these business owners. 

Sharon Douglas is the owner of POTERE CONSTRUCTION LLC, which provides industrial, municipal, commercial, private, and heavy highway construction services. A community leader with over 27 years of industry experience, Douglas is well-known for her work to build and support other small and diverse businesses in the Fort Worth, Texas, contracting community. She chairs the Fort Worth Metropolitan Black Chamber of Commerce  and hosts an online educational series to assist small and diverse construction businesses called ‚ÄúThings You Need to Know.‚Äù

‚ÄúI decided to start this show because I was getting calls from other small contractors having issues with contracts, certified payroll and other issues,‚Äù Douglas said. ‚ÄúThey were looking for a mentor. This show helps me to reach as many small contractors as possible, support them with answers that I didn't have as I got started, talk about building relationships, know your business, safety and what this means for your business, setting up the backroom to boots on the ground, training, and more.‚Äù

Teamwork and collaboration. That‚Äôs what made it possible to completely demo and replace Ottawa‚Äôs Booth Street Bridge in just 76 hours last weekend.

Highway 417, or Queensway, is a major thoroughfare in the city. A 5-kilometre section was originally scheduled to be closed for 82 hours to allow crews to replace the bridge using the rapid-bridge replacement approach.

During that time, crews needed to demolish the bridge, move the new bridges ‚Äì which were prefabricated offsite over the course of a year prior ‚Äì into place, and pave and paint traffic lines. 

Working around the clock through the weekend, the stretch was reopened on August 14, six hours ahead of schedule and before Monday‚Äôs morning commute.

Congratulations to the Kiewit-Dufferin team, as well as our client and business partners. And a big thank you from the entire team to commuters in the City of Ottawa for their patience and support!

When Kiewit began work in August 2019 on Michigan‚Äôs Indeck Niles Energy Center at the brownfield site, a former railyard, there were plenty of challenges for the team to tackle. 

One happened early in the process, said Project Manager Tyler Jeziorski.

"The water table is roughly 8 feet below grade, so all of the underground utilities, pipe and electrical duct banks were all in that water table. When you have contaminated soil, you can‚Äôt simply discharge water off the site."

"We had to essentially lower the water table locally and rotate it around the project while we installed the underground utilities and poured all the major foundations. To have adequate storage space to support these efforts, the team dug additional temporary retention ponds. It was a huge challenge for the job team to get that work done."

Learn more about the team‚Äôs efforts: http://ow.ly/FPq350IviO3

Four vessels at Australia Pacific Liquid Natural Gas (APLNG) on Curtis Island, Australia are filled with a special material that traps water at the molecular level, removing any last traces of water from the feed gas so it doesn‚Äôt freeze when it goes into the liquefaction section where temperatures drop to minus 160C (- 256F). The dryers provide a continuous flow of dry feed gas to the liquefaction section, by cycling through adsorption and regeneration modes in sequence. In any 48-hour period, each dryer is in adsorption mode for 36 hours followed by regeneration mode for 12 hours before being returned to adsorption mode. This winning photo was taken by Training & Competency Supervisor Carl Gibson. Learn more about APLNG: https://bit.ly/3AZxnf0

Have you ever wondered how we power our APLNG facility? Rotating equipment is the beating heart of our LNG plant, with twelve gas turbines driving compressors to push fluids through heat exchangers to liquify natural gas. Another seven gas turbines generate power to drive hundreds of fans, removing heat to allow the gas to condense. Rotating equipment keeps LNG moving, allowing us to supply energy on a global scale! We know our products inside and out, but do you? Here's an #FAQ about which side faces out when installing USG Durock¬Æ Brand Cement Board!
‚óÜ
‚óÜ
‚óÜ
‚óÜ
It does not matter which side faces out when installing Durock¬Æ Brand Cement Board. In fact, regardless of the side chosen, you can still expect the same performance with every installation. The purpose of having one smooth side and one textured side on USG Durock¬Æ Brand Cement Board allows for easy application of mastic (smooth side) and thin-set mortar (textured side). That said, mastic or thin-set mortar is suitable for either side of the board without compromising performance!

We are thrilled to share that USG is investing $210 million to build a brand new, state-of-the-art wallboard manufacturing plant in Wheatland County, Alberta. Construction is planned to begin in 2023, and the plant will create 100+ long-term, high-value manufacturing jobs.

Life insurance stats:

- Over 40% of Americans are not covered by some form of life insurance.*
- Most people overestimate the cost of life insurance by three times or more.**
- 106 million adults are in need of life insurance -- or more of it.*
- Within six months, 44% would feel unprepared financially after the death of a primary wage earner.*
- Men are much more likely than women (53% vs. 46%) to own life insurance.* This is a #gendergap issue that we can close. 

Life insurance is a tool that helps you protect all you've been given, so you can continue to bless others -- even when you're gone. https://bit.ly/3CmE9fB

*2022 Life Insurance Barometer, LIMRA
**2021 Life Insurance Barometer, LIMRA

Thrivent's 2022 Consumer Financial Outlook Survey found that inflation is pushing many Americans off track financially, getting in the way of saving and impacting their ability to focus on their financial priorities. 

Inflation is also causing a higher percentage of Americans to prioritize short-term financial goals, like increasing income, boosting emergency savings and paying off loans/debt. This may come at the expense of thinking about longer-term goals, like retirement savings investments or child's college education. For the survey's full findings üëâ https://bit.ly/3TQzSbc

If you're feeling the impact from inflation, Thrivent can help you build healthy budgeting, saving and spending habits. Life insurance stats:

- Over 40% of Americans are not covered by some form of life insurance.*
- Most people overestimate the cost of life insurance by three times or more.**
- 106 million adults are in need of life insurance -- or more of it.*
- Within six months, 44% would feel unprepared financially after the death of a primary wage earner.*
- Men are much more likely than women (53% vs. 46%) to own life insurance.* This is a #gendergap issue that we can close. 

Life insurance is a tool that helps you protect all you've been given, so you can continue to bless others -- even when you're gone. https://bit.ly/3CmE9fB

*2022 Life Insurance Barometer, LIMRA
**2021 Life Insurance Barometer, LIMRA

Thrivent's 2022 Consumer Financial Outlook Survey found that inflation is pushing many Americans off track financially, getting in the way of saving and impacting their ability to focus on their financial priorities. 

Inflation is also causing a higher percentage of Americans to prioritize short-term financial goals, like increasing income, boosting emergency savings and paying off loans/debt. This may come at the expense of thinking about longer-term goals, like retirement savings investments or child's college education. For the survey's full findings üëâ https://bit.ly/3TQzSbc

On my first day at Starbucks, my apron was ready for me with my name tag, ‚ÄúCici,‚Äù and my manager had set it up with a pin that said ‚Äúbienvenidos‚Äù which means welcome in Spanish. As a Mexican American, it made me feel like I could be myself.

I lived in Rio Rico, AZ (which is just outside of the Mexico border) until I was 18, when I first moved to Tempe, AZ. It was kind of a culture shock because suddenly I was surrounded by so many different cultures.¬†

That first day at Starbucks was just the beginning of feeling like it was my new home. Soon, so many other Latinx customers would come in and I was able to communicate with them in Spanish and English. It‚Äôs helped me connect with them in a deeper way.

Now, I work with so many people from different cultures. It is so awesome to share our differences, and all come together working for a company we love.

I just feel extremely thankful for working at Starbucks because I don't see it as just a job--I see it as my career. I wake up every morning and I'm just so excited to come to work. I love building confidence for my team, helping them also move up with the company.¬†

This Latinx Heritage Month, I'm reflecting on my pride to be the daughter of a single working mom. I'm so proud of her for coming to the states at such a young age. Without my mom, I wouldn‚Äôt be where I am today. This month reminds me of how hard my mom worked in order for my siblings and I to live the American dream.¬†

- Cici, Shift Supervisor in Tempe, AZ (nominated by the Starbucks Hora del Caf√© Partner Network)

‚ÄúThis #DisabilityPrideMonth at Starbucks, I am discussing with my partners (employees) what it means to ‚ÄúCome as You Are.‚Äù My name is Peter (he/him), and I am a Starbucks store manager, and I also live with both apparent and nonapparent disabilities.

I live my day to day with Severe Social Anxiety coupled with post-traumatic stress disorder, significant hearing loss, limited mobility in my left hand due to reconstructive surgeries, as well as Osgood-Schlatter‚Äôs Disease which limits my mobility. During my time in the US Marine Corps, I also suffered a traumatic brain injury which has led to short-term memory loss.

Beyond the lifelong impacts of my time in the Corps I also am a person living with Asperger‚Äôs Syndrome. I have changed my day-to-day life to accommodate some of the unique obstacles this may present, and my partners (employees) are all incredibly supportive of me and the challenges that may occur due to how my mind works.¬†¬†

In all my years of employment, I have never felt a stronger sense of belonging to something important aside from my military service‚Äî until Starbucks. Starbucks has given me the opportunity to positively impact others in a meaningful way.¬†

This Disability Pride Month, I am reflecting on our growing awareness of how many people think and feel differently, and how that brings more acceptance toward those who think in unique ways. Whether it is trauma that someone is dealing with, or a loss that someone is working through‚Äî sharing our journeys brings that awareness to it.

Our mission ‚ÄúTo inspire and nurture the human spirit, one person, one cup, and one neighborhood at a time‚Äù is a mantra I believe in. I have become the type of person that wants to go to work even during my off time.¬†Starbucks fulfills that promise of what it wants to be, and that allows me to be who I am.‚Äù

-	Peter G., Store Manager, Austin Texas

This Disability Pride Month, join us as we build more inclusive communities alongside the Disability Advocacy Partner Network through positive actions and allyship. Learn more at: https://lnkd.in/ghE3N5hF

"Starbucks is where I grew up. It‚Äôs where I learned the power of connection. It‚Äôs where I learned that everyone has a story. I started my journey with Starbucks in 2004 as a Barista. Within three years, at the age of 23, I was opening and managing a store. It was my pride and joy.¬†

After eight years, I hung up the green apron. I needed to tell stories. In the years that followed, I earned my M.A. in Journalism from Columbia College Chicago, worked in news media in Chicago and the Twin Cities, managed storytelling at a global nonprofit and gained corporate communications experience at a [Electronics Company].¬†

While working at a nonprofit, I even went back to Starbucks as a part-time shift supervisor. Now, I am proud to write stories for [a Healthcare Technology] employee audience. My experience in journalism, nonprofit and corporate communications is built on a foundation of skills I learned as a store manager for Starbucks. In Vietnamese culture, family is not about being blood related‚Äîit‚Äôs about the support someone has given you, Jenny says. To Jenny, the partners she‚Äôs met at Starbucks are her family, guiding and supporting her since she started at Starbucks in 1995.
¬†
Originally starting as a barista, Jenny is now a district manager in California and a leader of the Pan-Asian Pacific Network (PPN), one of many partner-led communities that bring those with shared experiences and identities across Starbucks together. For Jenny, the community has brought a deeper understanding to the importance of hearing people‚Äôs stories as well as sharing her own as a Vietnamese American.
¬†
‚ÄúEvery culture and every community has gone through pain, celebration, and love. All those feelings are the same,‚Äù Jenny says. ‚ÄúListening to someone‚Äôs story creates a more inclusive environment, because it creates a sense of unity, allowing us to learn more about everyone else so we can be more accepting.‚Äù
¬†
Throughout her journey at Starbucks, Jenny has gotten married, had four children, and over the last few years, questioned what might be next for her career. In the end, when she thought of the community of people who supported her through it all, the answer was Starbucks.¬†
¬†
‚ÄúWhen my dad passed away, my partners that had worked for me over the years and the community, including my RVP, all showed up at my dad's funeral‚Ä¶‚Äù Jenny recalls. ‚ÄúAs I'm thinking about that, I had just an overpouring [feeling] of, this is where I'm supposed to be.‚Äù
¬†
We are so proud to be your partner, Jenny. To learn more about Pan-Asian Partner Network and other partner networks, click here: https://lnkd.in/g7YyXax5

‚ÄúIf you asked me when I started a new job at Starbucks as a barista if I had considered the Starbucks College Achievement Plan program, I would‚Äôve shrugged my shoulders and said, ‚Äònot for me. I want the full in person college experience.‚Äô¬†
¬†
At the time I was a new high school graduate, anxious about starting a new job, scared to begin my college journey at my local community college, lost from the recent death of a parent, and confused with all the choice and opportunities ahead of me.
¬†
Over the years, many aspects of my life have changed. My father has been my absolute greatest, most supporting, patient and impactful person in my SCAP journey. He never went to college and knew he couldn‚Äôt always help me in the way that I needed. Yet, he was the only person who would stay up sitting at the kitchen table in silence while I try to write a paper, sobbing because I felt so defeated.
¬†
My father impacted by SCAP journey by unconditionally supporting me and reassuring me that failure oftentimes leads to new beginnings, hard times never last forever and it doesn‚Äôt matter how long it takes you to finish the race ‚Äì as long as you finish and believe that you‚Äôve already won.
¬†
[Today, 5 years later since starting at Starbucks] I realized my SCAP journey isn‚Äôt just saying I have a piece of paper to prove I‚Äôm educated, intelligent and worthy. Rather, my journey, jobs, relationships, and hardships are leaving a lasting impact on myself and the world around me. I am in fact an educated, intelligent and worthy‚Äîsometimes it just takes a push into the unknown to figure that out.‚Äù
¬†
-¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Sara S., shift supervisor and May 2022 SCAP graduate

For Gena, being a woman in the workplace sometimes feels like a balancing act.

‚ÄúCan we show emotion? If we are stern and firm will people receive that well? Do I need to dress a certain way?‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOn top of that, how can I be me? To me, it comes down to having the courage to be authentically you‚Ä¶often times we are expected to not bring a lot of that into work, but [ultimately] we are mothers, we are partners, we are sisters, we are daughters.‚Äù

As a 4-year partner, Director of Delivery in Digital Customer Experiences, co-chair of Starbucks Black Partner Network (BPN), and member of the Women's Impact Network (WIN), Gena has been defining what it means to be a changemaker and leader in the workplace.¬†

‚ÄúThere were times where I wondered where I would fit in‚Ä¶as I‚Äôve progressed in my career, I‚Äôve gained a certain level of confidence to just let myself show up as I am.‚Äù¬†

But she didn‚Äôt do it alone. Being raised by her late mother and growing up with three sisters created a strong support system as her foundation. As she got older, playing basketball grew her circle even more, giving her coaches and teams of diverse woman to learn from and grow with.

Today, she encourages her own teams to be the change they want to see.¬†

‚ÄúBe an entrepreneur in terms of creating that space and environment. If you don‚Äôt feel [included], someone else probably also feels that way. By putting yourself out there you‚Äôre creating an impact in how different people may think about initiating change.‚Äù

Thinking in two languages, (English and Shona, one of the national languages of Zimbabwe) Shami used to find herself struggling to find the correct words to say in meetings. Worried about what people may think, she stayed quiet.
¬†
‚ÄúAfter meetings, [my manager] would say, ‚ÄòI feel like you had something to say‚Äô and I‚Äôd say I did, but sometimes I didn‚Äôt feel like I had the right words or corporate jargon. He told me, ‚ÄòYou need to speak up, because there are probably people who feel the same way or are thinking the same thing, but aren‚Äôt courageous enough to say anything.‚Äô‚Äù¬†
¬†
Years later, Shami is now a recruiting manager for Starbucks Technology, and thinks of her experience as a lesson to always empower her team with the confidence to speak their truth.
¬†
‚ÄúAt places I have worked before it‚Äôs more about the bottom line, but here at Starbucks, it‚Äôs all about the partners (employees). It‚Äôs all about putting people first and making sure everyone is seen and heard.‚Äù¬†
¬†
Calling herself a big people person, Shami says she can‚Äôt see herself anywhere else.

‚ÄúI believe in what we do in the day to day. I feel like I'm around very authentic people who care about one another. The other day my significant other heard me on a call and asked, ‚Äúdid you just say you love somebody else?‚Äù and I say ‚ÄúI sure did!‚Äù¬†
¬†

Only 3% of all lawyers globally are Black women‚Äî ‚Äãand Zabrina Jenkins, svp and deputy general counsel at Starbucks, is one of them.

As a 17-year partner (employee), Zabrina sometimes wonders if she would still be practicing law had she not decided to leave her firm for Starbucks. Her move was largely influenced by mentors helping guide her along the way.

‚ÄúLaw is a male dominated profession. I was attracted to Starbucks because the general counsel back then was an African American woman ‚Äì one of three or four at a Fortune 500 company at that time," she said. "Having someone who looked like me, who was a leader, who could understand and relate to the issues that I had faced and encountered, was inspiring and helped me grow as a professional and taught me a lot about being a business leader at a company.‚Äù

For Zabrina, the responsibility to mentor others was something she learned growing up. Today, some of her mentorship is given through her executive sponsorship of the Black Partner Network at Starbucks, which brings many Black partners together to connect, serve communities and support one another.

‚ÄúAt Starbucks, [our] company values align with my own‚ÄîI‚Äôve always said, if there comes a day where the company‚Äôs values and mine are not aligned, it‚Äôs time for me to leave. It‚Äôs a place where I can continue to grow and have a number of opportunities and still feel like my personal value system is honored.‚Äù

For those who may be uncertain but aspire to practice law, Zabrina advises ‚ÄúDo your homework and make an informed decision.¬†Don‚Äôt let your fears keep you from reaching your goal.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúYou are not characterized by your circumstances,‚Äù says Andrew, licensed store district manager.
¬†
As a first generation Nigerian American whose parents immigrated before he was born, Andrew faced challenges throughout his life where he was reminded of who he was, and who he wasn‚Äôt.
¬†
Visiting Nigeria for the first time at 9 years old, Andrew was humbled and inspired seeing where his parents came from. But during their time there, Andrew‚Äôs 12 year old brother developed malaria and after returning home to America, he passed away. Andrew watched how his parents remained dedicated to their faith, gaining strength and support during the difficult time.
¬†
‚Äú[It inspired] a strong belief in something bigger than myself. I would say that's the most tangible and pivotal thing that led from there. But also, I think [it put] just a hunger in me‚Äîbeing the only boy in the family, realizing I'm carrying on a legacy.‚Äù
¬†
Since then, Andrew has been dedicated to studying business, leadership and equity in the workplace and leading Starbucks licensed stores in the Indianapolis area. His passion for people and work culture has inspired his career as well as his authored book: The Circle of Leadership. For Andrew, being a good leader is about showing people empathy.
¬†
‚Äú[I want to have] awareness of who I'm talking to, what their struggles are, their backgrounds, I think that's important. Finding moments to create a safe space to open up and have some of those conversations and asking, ‚Äòhow are you really doing?‚Äô‚Äù
¬†
To Andrew, this behavior matches Starbucks Mission and Values. ‚ÄúThey're not just words that go on a wall or in a handbook. They're really trying to inspire and nurture the human spirit and take care of their partners.‚Äù
¬†
Join us this Black History Month as we celebrate the everyday¬†Black¬†excellence of our partners (employees) like Andrew. Explore more partner stories here:  https://lnkd.in/gBjnxXBb

‚ÄúWhere should I work?" Dennis Brockman, global chief inclusion and diversity officer at Starbucks, knows exactly what he‚Äôll say when his kids, grandkids and mentees ask for advice on who their future employer should be.
¬†
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt take your talent to a company who wants it because they need it,‚Äù says 14-year partner (employee), Dennis. ‚ÄúI want you to go to companies who did the work when I was coming up. I want you to reward your talent to the companies who have been doing this work, and not the companies who want your talent because they have no other choice, [because] they need you now.‚Äù
¬†
As the U.S. becomes more diverse, Dennis predicts that companies who didn‚Äôt prioritize #InclusionAndDiversity will struggle to survive.
¬†
‚ÄúInclusion and diversity is business imperative. It‚Äôs so important because of our partners, customers, communities and investors. If companies aren‚Äôt doing the work today, in this space, I truly believe those companies will not be in existence 20 years from now because they will not have the talent,‚Äù Dennis says.
¬†
At Starbucks, Dennis has been leading work to make sure our partners and customers feel a sense of belonging. In addition to Starbucks goal of increasing our spend with diverse suppliers to $1.5 billion by 2030, we‚Äôve also prioritized advancing programs dedicated to mentorship and career coaching of Black, Indigenous and People of Color (BIPOC) partners.
¬†
We believe there will always be work to do to nurture inclusion, and we continue to be dedicated to creating lasting change for our people and our communities. Learn more about Dennis Brockman's work and bold hiring goals:

September 30 marks the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation in Canada. This day honors the children who never returned home and Survivors of residential schools, as well as their families and communities. In observance of this day, we'd like to recognize PetSmart associate Henry. He's an Associate Lead in Canada and took the time to share his story and what Truth and Reconciliation Day means to him and his family. 

"Truth and Reconciliation Day is to know the truth about what our parents have lived through. To recognize that their resilience shines through in us, their children. We walk in their truth and hope to bring more understanding to our culture and how we live it in everything we do. As a part of the Cowichan Tribes, we are proud to say we love and respect all living beings and have a great amount of respect for PetSmart and the company's values for our pet parents and their pets. 

Continued education without judgment means we are truly healing as a nation and as a people. I'm very thankful for everything I have learned over the last three years at PetSmart, and I am grateful to belong, knowing I can share who I am with my store and district teams and now with all of PetSmart."

üëã Meet Kyle: Store Leader at Georgetown PetSmart 
‚ÄúI seek to support others' mental health by actively listening. As a leader, it is very easy to assign tasks, tell people what needs to be done or give business updates, but we sometimes lose focus on the most important part of any good business and that is the people running it. I always try to stay mindful of how others may be feeling and I have an open-door policy with all of my associates. Getting to know our associates on a little more personal level, learning about their families, favourite activities or past personal experiences allows us to create a warm, welcoming environment within our store.‚Äù

Thank you for all of your support, Kyle! We appreciate you so much and are thankful to have such a supportive leader within our pack. ü§©

We're so excited to announce the grand opening of the first Emancipet clinic in one of our¬†PetSmart¬†stores!

When PetSmart Charities first introduced the Everyday Adoption Centers in stores in 2010 to help more pets find homes, the hope was always that the programs would grow to do more than just create families, but to help keep them together.

The challenges many faces in obtaining access to veterinary care for their pets are one of the reasons PetSmart Charities works hard every day to equip their partners with the grants they need to help provide care for local communities. We're grateful to our PetSmart Charities team members and our PetSmart store associates for their dedication to pets and all who love them. We're proud of the work our partners do every day to make an impact.

For pets. For people. For good. üíô #LifeAtPetSmart #PetSmartCharities

üåç Ever wondered what the inside of one of our Unilever offices looks like? 

Today we are taking a tour around one of our Dutch offices - Hive in Wageningen.

Also known as the Foods Innovation Centre, Hive is the global Research & Development hub for many of our brands including Knorr, Hellmann's, and The Vegetarian Butcher. The location in Wageningen is no coincidence as the town sits at the heart of the world-renowned Food Valley!

Hive boasts more than 18,000m2 of area, including a built-in factory with a direct connection to the customer and food experience area. The material used for building the Wageningen office is approximately 30% recyclable, while its interiors use already recycled parts. 

The temperature inside is measured and adjusted based on the number of people present. In fact, the Innovation Centre has obtained the BREEAM-NL certification for architectural sustainability.

We‚Äôre nearing the end of our logo journey with one more part remaining! 

Each symbol in our U expresses a fundamental aspect of our company and what we are doing to make positive change in the world.

Heart: A symbol of love, care and health. It represents our commitment to helping people take small everyday actions to improve their health and wellbeing.

Transformation: A symbol of positive change or transformation. Our commitment to find new sustainable ways of doing business.

Plant: A symbol of the natural world we inhabit. It represents our commitment to reducing environmental impact across our value chain ‚Äì from how we source raw materials, to our manufacturing operations, to the way consumers cook, clean and wash with our products.

Particles: A reference to science and our ongoing commitment to find new innovative ways to improve the lives of our consumers.

Virtuous Cycle: A continuous, virtuous circle that represents our work to reduce the waste associated with the disposal of our products.

This week's tips come from the Global Human Resources Business Partner Ice Cream,¬†Sabine Greijmans.

Sabine started her journey with us five years ago when she joined the Unilever Future Leaders Programme within Human Resources. After the traineeship, she became the Human Resources Business Partner for the Refreshment department.

Sabine says, "The secret that got me this far in my career is to take life seriously, but not too serious. Any challenge in work and life can be tackled in one way or another, even if it sometimes needs ice cream or a hug. In any challenge or opportunity, try to step back and see the bigger picture. What is the impact you want to make? What do you want to stand for? Wherever you are on your journey, do what gives you energy and enjoy it!"

Today we‚Äôre heading over to our office in Bonifacio Global City (BGC) in Taguig, Manila, Philippines. üåè

Our office in Manila has forged a culture of Malasakit, a ‚Äúgenuine concern for others‚Äù, and actively engages employees to Win with Purpose. Our Summer 2022 Retail Development Program (RDP) wrapped up recently with graduation and a celebration for the 28 participants! 

These amazing associates completed a 12-week training program where they gained insight into all aspects of Belk's business, in addition to juggling the daily functions of their roles.
 
Here‚Äôs a small snapshot of what their summer looked like:

‚Ä¢Acquired knowledge of key areas of the business including Private Brands, DEI, Supply Chain, Marketing, Community Relations, eCommerce, and more

‚Ä¢Learned retail math, reporting, monthly forecasting, assortment planning, and Excel

‚Ä¢Received an average of 25 hours of systems training

‚Ä¢Spent time with multiple senior leaders in informal Q&A sessions

‚Ä¢Toured multiple stores, as well as our in-house Photo Studio

‚Ä¢Spent two working days in one of our stores doing everything from floor sets, to order fulfillment, and unloading trucks

‚Ä¢Toured one of our distribution centers
 
It was an action-packed program, full of learnings and a lot of fun! This is an eager, inquisitive, and ambitious group of associates, and we can‚Äôt wait to see what they accomplish in the future. 

Additionally, we‚Äôd like to extend a huge thank you to the presenters, trainers, managers, mentors, Store Managers, and everyone else who supported this group.
 
Congratulations to the Summer 2022 RDP group!

#belk

Hurricane Ian has left a long road to recovery for those affected by one of the most damaging storms to hit the U.S. mainland. Even before the hurricane made landfall, our associates sprang into action to work on a plan to help those who were impacted at our locations along the storm‚Äôs path.
 
Our Distribution Center teams showcased what they do best, by coordinating efforts to make sure that critical supplies (like tarps, Clorox, batteries, soap, and bottled water) were on the first trucks delivered to stores following the storm. Those teams were able to pull from our existing supply of bottled water to get water to our affected stores in record time, and they even ran out to shop for tarps to make sure they could provide all the needed supplies for recovery efforts.
 
It's times like these that show how we truly are One Belk, and we‚Äôre so thankful for the Distribution Center associates who quickly came together to help out their teammates in this time of need.

We love being part of our communities, and for over 130 years, we have always encouraged associates to find opportunities to give back. 

Our Snellville, GA store team had a wonderful day where they surprised a customer of ours, Barby, who has been shopping at Belk for over 43 years!
 
Atlanta-based fashion and style influencer Kenzie Crouch of @stylingwithkenzie had recently posted a video with Barby who happened to tell Kenzie that Belk is her favorite place to shop. After several of our associates saw the video and fell in love with Barby, they knew they wanted to do something special. It turns out that Barby is a caregiver for her husband who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, and once we learned that we knew we definitely wanted to do more for her.
 
In honor of Barby and her husband, Belk made a $2,500 donation to the Alzheimer‚Äôs Foundation. But instead of simply making a donation on their behalf, our Snellville, GA associates invited Barby to her local store for a personal styling session. We gave Kenzie a $250 Belk gift card to use as she shopped with Barby, and then our store team surprised them with an additional $500.
 
"I felt just like a queen for the day! It was just wonderful," Barby said.
 
Thank you to all our associates who made this experience possible for one of our long-time customers!
 
You can watch the video from Barby‚Äôs special day at Belk with our Snellville, GA team and Kenzie here:
https://bit.ly/3Rz6eWa

At Belk, we support associates who wish to volunteer by encouraging them to use hours throughout the year, because we have a legacy of giving back to our communities. 
 
Recently, members from our Finance and Legal teams spent a day volunteering with Junior Achievement (JA) of Central Carolinas. This nonprofit works to inspire and prepare young people to succeed, with a focus on under-served students and schools.
 
The Belk team led a group of Indian Land, SC middle school students through a life skills simulation at Camp North End in Charlotte, NC. Across our footprint, associates continue to mark Black History Month in a variety of ways.
 
Associates at our Lynchburg, VA store partnered with the Legacy Museum of African American History in Lynchburg to showcase historical installations inside the store that highlight local Black history.
 
Store Manager Michael B. said, "I've been humbled by the interactions with my team and our guests. I've observed guests coming into the store specifically to see the displays. They took pictures and were sharing stories of their family's history here in Lynchburg and the surrounding areas. Our community is engaging with Belk at an emotional level."
 
"It's held great meaning for us that we've been able to do something special for our community that is free and educational, and supports Black lives and history in our community," said Michael. "I'm very proud of the connection we're making with our community and associates through this partnership."
 
If you're in the Lynchburg area, please join our associates there for a special in-store event on Saturday, 2/19 from 1-3 PM ET that will feature local authors and a book signing.
 
Kudos to the Lynchburg team for building these incredible connections with their community!

Succession planning isn‚Äôt as hard as it may seem. Seven steps can ensure it‚Äôs done correctly.

Gift card fraud is on the rise. Synovus and other financial institutions have been made aware of a social media scam requesting financial assistance in the form of gift cards. After the gift cards are sent, the individual states the gift cards do not work and will give the customer instructions that lead to the customer calling fraudulent phone numbers. The final goal is for the customer to scan a QR code at a Bitcoin ATM at which point their account is drained. Stay Alert!

DO make sure it‚Äôs legit. Scammers see an opportunity to take advantage of your generosity so it‚Äôs important to do your homework before making a contribution.

DO trust your gut. Social engineering scams try to cash in on personal hardships and use scare tactics and a sense of urgency to get you to act quickly. 

DO look for reliable alternatives to make donations. It‚Äôs a good idea to search organization names on a charity watchdog site, like GuideStar and Charity Navigator.

DO protect your payments. The Federal Trade Commission recommends avoiding cash, gift cards, and money wires as payments, suggesting you stick to credit cards or checks instead.

If you think you‚Äôve been a victim of fraud, call 888-SYNOVUS (796-6887) immediately.

Are you #RedRaven Ready? 

Industries around the world gather equipment performance data through remote condition monitoring and predictive maintenance to improve operational efficiency, focus maintenance efforts, improve safety and reduce operating costs.

Most #Flowserve fluid motion and control equipment is RedRaven Ready ‚Äî designed and built to accept RedRaven wired or wireless sensors, using cloud architecture for condition monitoring and predictive analytics services. The freeze on federal student loan payments has been extended more than six times since it was first passed in March 2020 as part of the $2.2 trillion Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act. Though there is the possibility that the White House may extend this relief again, the current moratorium is set to expire on August 31, 2022.

If you're concerned about what the end of this moratorium could mean for you, here's a quick guide with resources for student loan refinancing and repayment, an overview on loan relief programs‚Äîand even how to check and see if your student loan has possibly been canceled completely.

For #InventorsDay, we thought it fitting to recognize the lineage of inventors who have brought us to today's modern oscilloscopes.

Oscilloscope history begins in the 19th century when French Physicist Andre Blondel captured the first recorded waveforms on a galvanometer which detected changes in the current that was recorded by manually drawing a diagram of the wave formations.

William Duddell created the photographic oscillograph which used a mirror galvanometer that allowed waveforms to be measured and recorded directly.

In 1897 the cathode-ray tube, invented by Karl Ferdinand Braun, made it possible to record higher frequency measurements and led to the design of the first analog oscilloscope.

In 1946 Howard Vollum and Melvin Murdock developed the first triggered oscilloscope ‚Äî the Tektronix Model 511. It allowed for more precise measurements as the waveforms were displayed and then repeated to create a stronger graphed image.

Since then, oscilloscope development has grown exponentially. After 76 years, Tektronix is still the lead producer of oscilloscopes. Without innovators like Blondel, Duddell, Braun, Vollum, and Murdock, Tektronix would not be here today. Happy Inventors Day!

Learn more about Howard Vollum, Melvin Murdock and a brief history of Tektronix here: https://lnkd.in/gfNNieVj

#OregonHistroy #Oscilloscope #Tektronix #Tektastic

I‚Äôve spoken many times about the importance of partnership as we tackle the energy transition and develop New Energies solutions.  In that spirit, I‚Äôm delighted to share that today Chevron announced a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Air Liquide, Keppel Infrastructure and PetroChina to create a consortium that intends to evaluate and advance the development of large-scale carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) solutions and integrated infrastructure in Singapore.  

Through research, testing and operational solutions, the consortium aims to provide industry-wide CCUS infrastructure to support the energy and chemicals sector by capturing CO2 emissions to utilize for making useful products like plastics and cement, or by transporting the CO2 to geological reservoirs in the Asia Pacific region for permanent and secure storage.
 
We believe that the future of energy is lower carbon.  This strategic alliance with like-minded collaborators will help us progress and advance the development of large-scale CCUS solutions in the Asia Pacific region for decades to come.

Our tug boats on Barrow Island had some very special visitors last weekend, with a female humpback whale and her calf swimming into the boat pen while on their annual migration between the¬†Kimberley and the Antarctic.

We've seen plenty of sea turtles,¬†small sharks and groups of dolphins¬†‚Äì and even rare sightings of dugongs -¬†¬†but this is the first time we‚Äôre aware of that a pair of whales have been seen in the pens.

Migrating whales make stops to rest and feed their calves, and as with many locations along the WA coast,¬†they are common¬†around Barrow Island during the migration season. In this case, they stayed in the pens for around 40 minutes before continuing on their journey.

Thanks to Cindy and Rima from Toll for capturing this incredible footage!

So many #manufacturing innovations made #TeamBoeing a leader in aerospace.

Following World War I, engineers focused on designing more practical and efficient aircraft. Traditional stick, wire and fabric construction gave way to a welded steel framework and duralumin. In 1923, Boeing engineers successfully devised the process of arc-welding light steel tubing. This innovation was used to build the PW-9, the first Boeing-designed fighter.
